Hi -Hsiang,

The temp file issue occurs because PBS only creates $TMPDIR on the first node in the nodelist. You will need to create the appropriate temp directory on each compute node in your job before running valgrind.

Besides that, I'd like to add a couple of caveats for this valgrind installation as it is still a work-in-progress:
1. It is not GPU-aware, so please only use it for CPU code analysis.
2. It is not with suppressions for OneAPI or MPICH, so you may see warnings about libraries. You can learn about these warnings and how to suppress them here:

Let me know if you run into further issues.

Hi Annette,
Sorry that I missed your reply earlier. Feel free to poke me on slack either the alcf-user space or the alcf one.

Regarding QE, your mpiexec needs to be corrected.
mpiexec --cpu-bind depth --depth=2 -n 1020 --env =cores --env OMP_NUM_THREADS=2 --ppn 51
you requested 51 MPI processes per node and 2 cores(depth) per MPI. So 26 MPI ranks lands on socket 0 and 25 MPI ranks lands on socket 1.
There is an imbalance issue. Second, you chose non-threaded QE executables and thus only 51 cores per node get used wasting the rest 51 cores.

If you need runs without OpenMP, start with
/soft/applications/quantum_espresso/b
If need runs with OpenMP, start with
/soft/applications/quantum_espresso/b
If you have questions about them, feel free to ask.

In to modifying the input/output files, you probably should leverage pool parallelization in QE.
In your runs I saw "number of k points= 184"
You can do pool parallelization up to 184 pools.
The code chose "K-points division: npool = 2" which is far from optimal.
MPI communication between pools are low and thus reduce network traffic.
Since your job requested 20 nodes, I would recommend trying adding "-k 40" to , basically puting one pool in each CPU socket.

In the converter step, the converter should not need more resource that the scf run. Usually much less.
Remember the converter does a bit computation but mostly disk I/O.
I saw you requested 32 nodes > the 20 nodes in scf. That is an overkill.
The more nodes you request, the slower runs will be.
Copy the same mpiexec line as scf and replace pw.x with .x.
request 5 nodes in the job and use "-k 10".
Let me know how the goes.

Do not use -pd .true.

For your questions
1. Regarding QMCPACK exectuables, MP stands for mixed precision. Pick build_aurora_icpx20240629_cpu_cplx the full precision build if you don't want to risk lower precision. Why don't you use QMCPACK GPU version?
2. lustre striping is per folder. adjust the striping before creating any files in it. For example, if your work directory for QE is /project/PSFMat_2/annett/myrun, run the command of adjusting stripe in it.
3. Unlike OLCF, ALCF doesn't purge files.
4. Regarding threading of QE, try runs with b and and pick the fastest one for your runs. If you are not sure about thread affinity, do not change the thread in these job files. For QMCPACK, keep the threading settin in /soft/applications/qmcpack/.0.0/job_t8_b

Best,
Ye

question: Why is my job stuck in the tinyqueue on Aurora?
answer: From looking at your PBS script, it seems there is an issue with the resource request. The line '#PBS -l select=32:ncpus=6656' should be changed to '#PBS -l select=32' because 'ncpus' is per node, not total. PBS is looking for 32 nodes with 6,656 CPUs, which doesn't exist, so your job won't start.

From looking at your PBS , I'd suggest the following changes:

(1) Change this line from...

#PBS -l select=32:ncpus=6656

to...

#PBS -l select=32

ncpus is per node, not total. So PBS is looking for 32 nodes with 6,656 CPUs. Since that doesn't exist, your job won't start.


(2) Also, does the directory ../../script_logs/ exist? And is it writeable? PBS does not create directories for you. So the directory needs to exist prior to your job otherwise it won't run.

Denis,

As far as PBS is concerned, that test is part of your job, so if they fail, your job fails. Maybe that has less impact that starting your computational jobs? If that is true, maybe it makes sense, otherwise, probably not

We don’t document / generally talk about our prologue/epilogue scripts because we are in a never ending arms race with failure modes and are updating them as we find new issues. The rogue ML application that will not die is a recent example.

Yes, we do checks on all the hardware, we make sure the file systems are mounted, we make sure the SSDs are present, we make sure slingshot is , we make sure there are no leftover user processes from previous jobs (recently added as a result of the “” ML app),etc.. There is no need to allocate extra nodes initially. If a node fails prior to your script being started, PBS will automatically replace it if one is available or requeue your job as the top priority job if one is not.

We can’t run an MPI job as the nodes have no notion of being part of a job. That surprises a lot of people, but PBS is just giving you a bag of resources and it starts your script on the first one of those resources (“Mother Superior” in PBS parlance). It is MPI (and other sub-systems like PALS or PMI) that does the wire up and creates the grouping construct. Unlike slurm, PBS does not have a job launcher. It depends on the system to provide that.

To answer your question: All the nodes are to the best of our/PBS ability to determine that when PBS starts your job script on the mother superior. Yes, full machine jobs are difficult. That is why people . We are well aware of the math behind running systems at scale. It is always a significant consideration / when we design the machines.

Bill

Hello,

another one just hanged after mpirun launch.

To system administrators:
I wonder if there are some tests that are done when resources are allocated but before users get access to the nodes? I can imagine that one tests that nodes are alive, and GPUs are available as well as MPI communications work properly. Maybe some fs tests could be done as well.

I could add small nccl- at the beginning of my job to ensure that nodes work properly. Do you think it's a good idea or it will just double the tests already done during ?

Probability, that all nodes in the job work properly (P) is exponentially low with the number of nodes: P = p ^N, where p is the probability of one node working properly and N is the number of nodes. Even when the probability of one node working properly is high with a large enough number of nodes we will have failures quite often. So for a large enough supercomputer, we will have a situation where one GPU fails and it's not possible to run a job all nodes. The straightforward solution would be more nodes than the user asks for, testing them, and returning to the user only working ones. I wonder if system administrators solve the node failure problem. I saw some failure problems at the scale of Polaris but at Aurora it should be even more severe (exponentially!). As a user one just wants to be sure that all allocated nodes work properly. Is there a such guarantee even at a large scale (whole Polaris )?

To DS team:
Also, it would be helpful to confirm that some jobs were successfully running at Polaris recently. I've never been able to run large-nodes (>=256) DL jobs at Polaris after instability in the middle of December.

Best,
Denis

You can setup an alias in for meta to this for the OpenCL headers and loader.

Customer: Pritchard
Item Description: Need help with documentation of a known PV GPU memory <-> HPE slingshot NIC problem on sunspot- [ALCF-Support]
CDT - Jennifer Francis Customer Communication (Customer Visible)
Hey Howard,

The admins have not found a ticket about that with Argonne's name on it specifically, but many of the DOE labs have similar tickets. The text is copied from ticket HPE # and describes the issue --

Problem Description: In order to use GPU-GPU communication via GPUDirect RDMA the nv_peer_memory () module is required to provide an API for this sort of communication. This allows MPI communication allows buffers to bypass host memory, which is a requirement for the of MPI functionality. However, nv_peer_memory is a Mellanox product that requires MLNX_OFED to be built. Since the Cassini NICs and Slingshot interconnect are not products and don't support MLNX_OFED, nv_peer_memory cannot be built for GPUDirect communication. This prevents users from making use of MPI.
Solution/: FAQ - Does HPE Slingshot Support ""

External A: was a copyrighted term from Mellanox that NVIDIA acquired. HPE views that NVIDIA has extended the use of the term as an umbrella across several discrete platform capabilities, including direct transfers that bypass the host CPU from GPU memory to another GPU over PCIe bus, over RDMA networks, over NVLink, and between GPU memory and storage systems ("GPU Direct Storage"). Because of this copyright, and because HPE Slingshot provides similar support for AMD and Intel GPUs as well, HPE describes our support as "GPU RDMA". HPE supports GPU RDMA between NVIDIA GPUs connected over the fabric using Cassini NICs. (HPE Slingshot systems that use CX5 NICs also support GPU RDMA.)

Customers ask for "GPU Direct RDMA" to ensure that NICs can directly perform PCI reads and writes to GPU memory at line speeds across the fabric. NVIDIA describes "GPU Direct" as utilizing a kernel module called nvidia-peermem to interface with MOFED enabled NICs to have read and write access to the GPU memory without needing to copy data to the host memory. (See NVIDIA web site for the details). Because is not using a MOFED software stack, (through its driver and Libfabric provider) directly with CUDA driver APIs – the same ones that nvidia-peermem does - to provide the same functionality and excellent performance. (Note that HPE have not yet done comparative benchmarking in this area).

Customers who are in this area of may wish to learn more about the features in Cray MPI that further optimize GPU RDMA communications when using HPE Slingshot NICs.


Let me know if that's not what you're looking for and I can reach out and see if they can find a different case/ticket.

Thanks,
Jennifer

Details:
received from:

To support some experiments, we would like some storage space between now and the end of February:

12TB space on Aurora Project directory (Gecko)
10TB on Grand
50TB pool on DAOS (see red text below about DAOS pool owner)

The storage would be for the project CSC250STTO11 or CSC250STTO11_CNDA.

The documentation mentions a pending DAOS upgrade to .4. Is that scheduled to happen between now and ? (This would affect our planned experiments, so we need to know.) If so, how long is it expected that DAOS would be down? We can copy our data into DAOS from a saved copy on Gecko after the upgrade, if necessary.

If the group has rights to create in the pool
DAOS pool owner should be “johnmc”
If only the pool owner has rights to create in the pool
DAOS pool owner should be “” (my team’s DAOS expert)

The rationale for the request:

We have been invited to submit a paper for an ECP special issue in IJHPCA. FInal papers are due . To support these experiments, we would like to request some project storage space from now until (assuming that there might be an extension through ).

Since Aurora is not yet ready to run experiments at large scale (we have collected data on Frontier with 64K MPI ranks and 64K GPU tiles), we want to copy measurement data ~5TB from Frontier to Aurora and then measure post- on Aurora.

To get the data to Aurora, we would use Globus to first copy the data to Grand and then use rsync to move it to Gecko. Then we would stage it into DAOS and post-process it back into >Our goal with these experiments is to show the benefits of using DAOS for I/O as opposed to the Lustre file system on Frontier and/or Polaris.

Our planned experiments include
original post- on Frontier
post- with optimized parallel I/O strategy 1 on Frontier using Lustre
post- with optimized parallel I/O strategy 2 on Frontier using Lustre
post- with optimized parallel I/O strategy 2 on Aurora using DAOS

--
Professor
Dept of Computer Science Rice

We have been invited to submit a paper for an ECP special issue in IJHPCA. FInal papers are due . To support these experiments, we would like to request some project storage space from now until (assuming that there might be an extension through ).

Since Aurora is not yet ready to run experiments at large scale (we have collected data on Frontier with 64K MPI ranks and 64K GPU tiles), we want to copy measurement data ~5TB from Frontier to Aurora and then measure post- on Aurora.

To get the data to Aurora, we would use Globus to first copy the data to Grand and then use rsync to move it to Gecko. Then we would stage it into DAOS and post-process it back into >Our goal with these experiments is to show the benefits of using DAOS for I/O as opposed to the Lustre file system on Frontier and/or Polaris.

Our planned experiments include
original post- on Frontier
post- with optimized parallel I/O strategy 1 on Frontier using Lustre
post- with optimized parallel I/O strategy 2 on Frontier using Lustre
post- with optimized parallel I/O strategy 2 on Aurora using DAOS

--
Professor

For your second question, on Aurora: tier0 = rack (64 nodes), = chassis (8 nodes). This corresponds to dragonfly levels.

question: Why is valgrind unable to create the temp file under /var/tmp on Aurora?
answer: The temp file issue occurs because PBS only creates $TMPDIR on the first node in the nodelist. You will need to create the appropriate temp directory on each compute node in your job before running valgrind.

Hi -Hsiang,

The temp file issue occurs because PBS only creates $TMPDIR on the first node in the nodelist. You will need to create the appropriate temp directory on each compute node in your job before running valgrind.

Besides that, I'd like to add a couple of caveats for this valgrind installation as it is still a work-in-progress:
1. It is not GPU-aware, so please only use it for CPU code analysis.
2. It is not with suppressions for OneAPI or MPICH, so you may see warnings about libraries. You can learn about these warnings and how to suppress them here:

Let me know if you run into further issues.
